newsitem.title: UKRAINE: Ukraine trying to repay Germany for oil plant cash.
newsitem.headline: Ukraine trying to repay Germany for oil plant cash.

text.p: The Ukrainian government is working out how to pay off a 1993 German credit owed by the country's second-largest oil refinery.
Yuri Yekhanurov, head of the state privatisation agency, told parliament the credit was guaranteed by the government but he did not specify the amount.
"The credit, obtained by the Lisichansk oil refinery in 1993 from the Germans and insured by an Italian company, is due this month," he told deputies on Wednesday.
Interfax Ukraine news agency said the money was owed to West Deutsche Landesbank AG, and that the refinery in eastern Ukraine owed $40 million to various creditors.
Lisichansk, one of six refineries in Ukraine, is due to be privatised this year.

Yekhanurov said the group was considering selling a big stake in the refinery to an investor willing to pay the debts and ensure productivity at the plant, which refined 1.1 million tonnes of oil in the first six months of this year (equivalent to around 44,000 barrels per day).

Ukrainian refineries routinely processed up to 60 million tonnes of crude oil a year (some 1.2 million bpd) in the Soviet era, but last year they refined only 16.8 million tonnes (about 336,000 bpd), reflecting sharp declines in Russian crude oil supplies.
